content.webTitle: Tammy Abraham unfazed by England youngsters’ ‘golden generation’ tag

fields.headline: Tammy Abraham unfazed by England youngsters’ ‘golden generation’ tag
fields.bodyText: Tammy Abraham is almost too young to remember England’s original “golden generation”. But after watching his former team-mates from last year’s Under-19 European Championship become world champions in South Korea at the weekend, the 19-year-old Chelsea striker believes the country’s current crop of young players can handle the pressure that infamous moniker brings with it. Abraham, who scored 23 league goals last season on loan at Bristol City, could easily have been part of Paul Simpson’s Under-20 World Cup-winning squad had his services not been required in Poland this week. Instead, he was with the rest of Aidy Boothroyd’s Under-21 squad at St George’s Park as they prepared for this week’s European Championship when England completed their 1-0 victory over Venezuela. “It’s massively inspiring,” said Abraham. “We’re going into a massive tournament now with the Under-21s and it would be nice to end it on a blast. The boys are confident. We’ve had a great season. We just want to top off with a win. Some of the lads have played in the Premier League, in top teams, we have an amazing team. Hopefully we can show that. We’re all excited. We just have to prove it.” Yet while the promise of youth never quite materialised on the full international stage for David Beckham, Michael Owen et al, there was a genuine feeling of optimism as England’s players trained for the first time on Polish soil after arriving on Monday. Several of the players in Boothroyd’s squad were part of the side that won last year’s Toulon tournament for the first time in 22 years, while the likes of Abraham and Leicester’s Ben Chilwell will still be young enough to play in this tournament in two years’ time. Given the success he has enjoyed since representing England for the first time at Under-18 level, it’s perhaps no surprise that Abraham – or to give him his full name, Kevin Oghenetega Tamaraebi Bakumo-Abraham – did not appear phased by the comparison with that previous era. “We definitely can handle that tag,” he said. “We have guys who are talented, can work hard and have everything. It’s just about blending in and becoming one, not just thinking about yourself.” It is that last statement in particular that stands out about this England set-up. The continuity that has seen Gareth Southgate step into the senior role, with Boothroyd moving up from his role with the Under-20s, has clearly fostered a strong team ethic that Abraham, who was part of the England side that lost out to Italy in the semi-finals of the Under-19s last year, hopes they can replicate in Poland – starting with their opening match against holders Sweden on Friday. “Last year team bonding was really important. We were out there for a long while, longer than this time and we had to stay focused,” he said. “There are times you need more than talent and so you have to make sure you give your all and leave everything out there on the pitch. “You could see [the Under 20s] had no fear, they played with confidence. They all had a smile on their face. We have to show no fear as well, take our confidence into these games. Every age group is like family and the bond of the team should get us through, even if tough times come.” Abraham has admitted he remains unsure which club he will play for next season, with promoted duo Brighton and Newcastle understood to have lodged an interest with Chelsea in taking him on a season-long loan. “I haven’t spoken to Chelsea yet but they know I’m focusing on this tournament so the discussions will happen after,” he said. “I’m not too sure [where I will play] but hopefully it will be in the Premier League. After this season I need to take myself to the next level. That’s the type of person I am, I always want to do better. I always want to do more. So going into the new season my aim will be to top this one.” Joining Andrea Pirlo, Klaas Jan-Huntelaar and Alvaro Morata on the list of players to have won the Golden Boot at this tournament in recent years would certainly be a strong statement at a time when Chelsea’s forward options for next season are very much in flux. Despite being the only teenager in the England squad, that is very much in Abraham’s sights, although it is his desire to end the summer with his own winners’ medal that is really driving the player from Camberwell in south London. “I haven’t really had a look at who’s won the Golden Boot here before. But hopefully I can win it,” he said. “The Under-20s did the country so proud and we would love to follow in their footsteps by winning the Euros. Obviously being Under-21s we want to show we are the next up and coming players for the England squad, so there is a bit of pressure. But then we have some amazing lads so we think we can go far as well. We can’t have them bragging they won and we didn’t.”
